quote: Geordi, there should be a power utilization monitor over there...
This is highly unusual. The crew is not at Battle Stations. The ship is on Evacuation Alert.
Is that why Romulans were being transported to the Enterprise... ?
Take a look at this...
There's an energy feedback returning through the transfer beam. It's probably what overloaded the Enterprise's engine... and caused the core breach.
Perhaps the Warbird was trying to destroy the Enterprise.
I don't think so. According to this, the Romulans were trying to shut down the power transfer.
Whatever happened, this is beginning to look less and less like a Romulan attack...
Let's take a look at their engine output.
Geordi -- the engine core is completely inactive.
That's impossible. The Romulans use an artificial quantum singularity as their power source. Once it's activated, it can't be shut down.
Maybe we should take a closer look....
I think we found the problem...

It appears to be a highly focused aperture in the space-time continuum. Its energy signature matches that of the temporal fragments we observed earlier. However, it is approximately one point two million times as intense. I believe this may be the origin of the temporal fragmentation.
What are these dark spots?
(continuing, off tricorder) I am not certain. They exhibit complex bio-electric patterns. Very possibly organic.
Organic?
From their molecular configuration, it would seem --
The aperture is beginning to fluctuate. I believe we are --
I believe my tricorder emissions caused the temporal aperture to activate. I suggest we avoid exposing it to any further energy emissions.
When time resumed, did you observe any activity in the engine room that suggested what the Romulans were doing?
It appeared they were trying to eject the engine core.
I thought I heard one of the Engineers say something about the power transfer. Something about an energy feedback...
It looks like they were trying to stop whatever was happening here...
Mister La Forge -- from where you are can you determine what's happening on the Romulan Bridge?
I think so...
Wait... something's different here...
Data... was this man always standing right here --
He's going into neural shock!
We must get him back to the Runabout.
There's not enough time -- he's dying.
At least this way, he'll be alive in the other time frame... we might have a chance to save him later. Is the Romulan still alive?
Yes. However, I am getting unusual readings from his bioscan. I am not sure that he is a Romulan.
His cellular structures do not conform to any known species, and his bio-electric patterns are in a state of temporal flux. I do not believe that this being is native to our time continuum.
Mister Data... you said you discovered organic matter within the temporal aperture...
That is correct.
I want to take a closer look at those readings.
This is a bio-spectral analysis of the temporal aperture. The organic readings originated from these dark spots.
They appear to contain some sort of energy patterns... Can you isolate one of them and magnify?
It looks like a cellular cluster...
Its bio-electric patterns are similar to that of the alien. However, it is significantly less complex. The cellular structures appear to be in a state of mitosis.
Data. This could be some sort of... embryo...
It is possible. If I could scan the aperture further, I might be able to --
Captain.
Must... save... no...
Who are you?
This body is... not mine... it was necessary to assume it... to exist in your... time...
Why are you here?
We had to come... to save them... they were... in danger...
Who was in danger?
Our young... they will die... in the gravity well... it is artificial...
Artificial... gravity well... You mean, the Romulan engine core?
Yes... our young... are trapped... We must get them out... return them to our time...
His molecular structure is destabilizing.
How did your young become trapped in the core?
We must use a natural gravity well... to incubate our young... We thought the Romulan core... would suffice... it did not...
Captain -- I believe his species mistook the artificial singularity, which the Romulans use in their engine, for a natural one... a black hole. They tried to use it as a nest.
That's what deactivated the Warbird's engine core... so the Romulans sent out a distress call...
The Enterprise responded... found the Warbird suffering an apparent engine failure... and attempted a power transfer.
Power transfer... we must stop the power transfer... it has... ruptured time... it will destroy... our young...
I believe that when the power transfer made contact with the alien nest, it disrupted the space-time continuum.
Was it you who attacked the Enterprise?
Yes... we had to stop the power transfer...
Are there others like you here?
One other...
Do you know where he is? Can he help us restore normal time?
I estimate the core breach will consume the Enterprise in approximately seven hours, two minutes.
Is there a way to lock onto the core itself... beam it into space?
No, sir. We would need to surround the core with a subspace isolation field. It is not possible to generate a field of that magnituide from the Runabout.
Mister Data... when you scanned the temporal aperture with your tricorder... it caused time to move forward, and back again...
That is correct.
What if we found a way to reverse that process -- make time move backward... then forward.
We might be able to run time back to a point before the warp core breach occurred... and then find a way to prevent the power transfer. So when time moves forward again...
... The breach won't happen.
I can attempt to modify the tricorder's scan frequency. It might allow us to manipulate the temporal aperture's effects.
Make it so, Data.
If this works, we may not have much time to prevent the power transfer. We'll have to decide precisely where to be and what to do the instant time begins to move backwards...
Captain -- I have placed the tricorder in the Romulan engine room. Standing by.
Acknowledged. Counselor -- are you in position?
Ready, sir.
Alright, Mister Data.
Initiating tricorder emissions...
Captain -- the warp core breach has been reversed.
Be ready, Mister Data.
Aye, sir.
You must stop!
You must not initiate the power transfer.
I'm sorry, sir. I already have.
We must shut it down.
The transfer beam is at saturation, sir -- it can't be disengaged.
Computer -- place a Level three containment field around the warp core.
Containment field activated.
Captain?
No time to explain, Number One. Continue the evacuation of the Romulan ship. You'll find LaForge in the Romulan engine room -- beam him directly to Sickbay.
Step away -- now.
Deanna, it's okay -- he wasn't firing at me.
There was an alien here... who'd taken Romulan form. I was firing at her... The doctor got in the way.
Where did she go... ?
Status, Mister Data?
I was attacked by another alien, sir. I was unable to prevent the power transfer.
It cannot be disengaged and the containment field will fail in seventeen seconds. A core breach is again imminent.
Can we move the ship?
The feedback from the transfer beam would tear us apart.
Patch me into the navigational control on the Runabout.
Got it!
I'm bringing the Runabout in...
Mister Data?
The core breach has been prevented, sir.
Data -- it appears that severing the power transfer has not only prevented the core breach, but has also restored space-time to normal.
The alien who attacked me has vanished, sir.
The Warbird has vanished as well.
Judging from the residual temporal fluctuations... I believe they have returned to their own time continuum.
Captain?
It's going to take a little time to explain, Number One...
Captain's Log, Stardate 46945.3. We successfully evacuated the crew of the Romulan ship. We're on course to the Neutral Zone to bring them home.
Come in.
Where's that cat of yours?
Spot is sleeping, sir. Why do you ask?
No reason...
I've worked out the new rotation schedules. I'd like you to cross check the personnel assignments and notify all department heads.
Your new Bridge shift begins at twenty-three hundred hours.
Understood, sir.
Data, what are you doing?

Recent events have compelled me to study how humans perceive the passage of time. For example, I have often heard people comment that time seems to pass more "slowly" in one instance, or more "quickly" in another. Yet in reality, the actual passage of time remains fixed.
I guess everybody perceives time a little differently... it depends on the exact situation... how you're feeling...
I have been testing the aphorism that "a watched pot never boils". I have boiled the same amount of water in this kettle sixty-two times. In some cases, I ignored the kettle.
In others, I watched it intently. In every instance, the water reached its boiling point in precisely fifty-one point seven seconds.
It would appear that I am not capable of perceiving time any differently than my internal chronometer.
Why don't you turn it off?
Sir?
Data... people don't have internal chronometers. See what happens when you turn yours off.
Thank you, Commander. I will try that.
Just don't be late for your shift.
Good evening, Mister Data.
Actually, good morning, sir.
Ship status is --
No need to report. I'm just here to do some work of my own.
Yes, sir.
I'd like to talk to Doctor Mowray at his archaeological site on Landris Two. Please put it through to my Ready Room.
I am sorry, sir, but Stellar Cartography has requested a communications blackout while they run an experiment.
How long will it be?
Another three hours, twenty-two minutes.
I can override it if necessary.
No, no... it's not important.
Aye, sir.
Computer, display the latest excavation schematics from Landris Two.
Library computer is temporarily off-line.
Explain.
Library Systems have been allocated to Stellar Cartography.
Tea, Earl Grey. Hot.
Replicator systems are off-line at the request of --
Stellar Cartography...
What could they possibly be doing down there... ?
In or out, but close that door.
Just try to stand still.

It'll take a second for our eyes to re-adjust... Elevate to three-point-two. Good... we can do this... We're losing vertical alignment. Compensate... Gently, don't bump it. No, no -- hit the... Forget it. Lights.
Whoever you are, you just ruined four hours of work.
You might've taken the simple precaution of locking the door.
It's three o'clock in the morning --
Captain Picard...
You must be Lieutenant Commander Daren.
Yes, sir. I'm sorry. It's just we weren't expecting many people to be up at this hour.
You're new aboard the Enterprise. I think you'll soon learn to start expecting the unexpected.
That's why I put in for this assignment.
Excellent. Now perhaps you could tell me what was so important that it required depriving the ship's Captain of a cup of Earl Grey?
Earl Grey? No wonder you can't sleep.
Computer, bring replicators back on line and give me a cup of Daren herbal tea blend number three, hot.
You shouldn't be drinking a stimulant at this time of night. I think you'll like this.
I've programmed seven other blends into the replicator... You're bound to like one of them.
I look forward to sampling them.
I'm sorry if the system blackouts we requested inconvenienced you. We were taking very precise gravimetric readings -- it wouldn't have taken much to throw them off.
What are these readings for?
I'm trying to construct a mathematical model of an emerging star system. If it works, we'll be able to predict the configuration of a system that won't be formed for another two million years.
That's a long time to wait to find out if you're right.
I have a few things to do between now and then.
We'll arrive at the Borgolis Nebula in three hours, sir.
I understand it has unusual radioactive emissions -- I'm sure Stellar Sciences will find it an interesting study.
Commander Daren has already requested time on the main sensor array.
You have the Bridge, Number One.
Captain, I would like to remind you about our concert this evening in Ten-Forward. We will be performing Chopin's Trio in G minor.
I'll be there.
... the upshot is... we'll be close enough for you to slip away for a few days and see Wesley.
Wonderful, thank you, Jean-Luc.
This is delicious; what is it?
It's an herbal tea blend... I came across it in the replicator files.
Have you met any of the new crewmembers we took on at Starbase Two-eighteen?
In fact, I have a new Nurse. His name's Beck, he's an obstetrics specialist.
I met the new head of Stellar Sciences last night. Lieutenant Commander Daren.
Yes... Nella Daren. She was in Sickbay for a physical last week. I liked her. Very forthright.
Very.
Oh, I forgot to tell you... The Exogenics Journal accepted my paper for publication.
That's wonderful, Beverly.
I'm hoping to get a response from other scientists studying ribosomal replication. There's still no satisfying explanation for the genetic drift.

That journal is widely read. You'll probably be swamped with responses. Did you know it's possible now to predict the configuration of a star system that won't be formed for another two million years?
Really? No, I didn't...

It's quite intriguing. It's made possible by a rather complex mathematical construct based on fractal particle motion. And of course that's just the foundation... the modeling itself requires gravimetric wave inputs.
I see.
Well, I'm sure it sounds dry. Stellar cartography isn't everyone's cup of tea...
I'm sure it's fascinating.
Well... we'd better get to Ten Forward; we don't want to be late for the concert.
Your playing was remarkable.
Thank you, sir.
You're very talented.
I noticed that the applause tonight exceeded average decibel levels.
I guess that means they enjoyed themselves. I know I enjoyed playing.
That was obvious.
Excuse me. I have not yet congratulated Ensign Cheney.
I'll go with you.
I played piano for a while when I was young. But I never put in the practice time it takes to become truly proficient.
That was never my problem. In fact, my parents had to make me go out and play.
I wanted to ask you... during the second arpeggio in the first movement, I noticed you played an F minor chord instead of a diminished D.
You're a musician. What's your instrument? We should play some time.
I'm very much an amateur. But I must say, your choice in that arpeggio was delightful. Not at all what one expects to hear.
Well, Captain... now that I'm on your ship, maybe you should start expecting the unexpected.
Excuse me, sir.
I was hoping my people in Spectral Analysis could have another few hours on the main sensor array.
I'm sorry, the array's been allocated to Engineering; they're running some warp field tests.
If we go off-line now, we'll lose the gas flow pattern we've been tracking.
I understand that. But we've got other departments waiting to use the array.
We're at a critical juncture --
Commander.
I'll see what I can do about more time tomorrow.
Tomorrow... but --- (beat; she realizes this is the best she can get) Thank you, sir.
End playback.
Come.
Commander Daren.
I hope you don't mind me dropping by like this?
I'm delighted. Come in.
What kind of flute is that?
It's Ressikan.
I never saw one before.
They're not made anymore.
How long have you been playing?
A long time...
I'd love to hear you play sometime.
I'm not very good.
It doesn't matter, as long as you enjoy it.
Yes, but I wouldn't want to inflict it on anyone else.
May I try?
You're not holding it quite right...
Show me.
You're better than you think.
Please...
Really. We should play together.
There's... no piano here.
Oh, but there is.
I picked it up on Mataline Two. It's amazing.
Remarkable... (hoping to get out of this) Why don't you play something for me?
You start... I'll jump in.
What... shall we play?
What were you working on before I came in?
Bach... the third Brandenburg.
Perfect. Go ahead.
Sorry...
It's all right... you're not used to playing with anyone, are you?
Just the computer.
Well... I may not be as precise as a computer... but I think you'll enjoy it more.
Let's try something a little simpler. How about...
Very good! Now... let's have a little fun with it.
Try it. Improvise on the melody -- anything you want.
That's wonderful! Keep going...
Number One... my sparring partner cancelled for this afternoon. I was wondering if you wanted to join me?
Fencing, sir? I'm really not very good.
It doesn't matter... as long as you enjoy it.
Why not?
Excellent. Fourteen hundred hours, then.
You have a mild strain.
I've been playing the piano a lot... I guess the Captain and I overdid it a little last night.
The Captain?
He plays a kind of flute... Ressikan, I think he said.
Yes... but I didn't realize he played... duets.
He never did before. But he seemed to enjoy it. He's actually quite promising.
I see.
Tell me... have you known him long?
Yes. A long time...
He seems... somewhat isolated.
I'd say he's a private person... but not isolated.
There. That should help.
It feels much better. Thank you.
Good.
I was afraid I'd have to cancel.
Another duet?
Where are we going?
Keep climbing.
I don't see why we can't just practice in my quarters.
We're almost there.
Do you know where we are?
The fourth intersect of Jefferies Tube twenty-five.
No... this is the most acoustically perfect spot on the ship.
The intersection acts as a resonance chamber.
How did you find it?
A little exploring.
Don't tell me you climbed through every tube on the ship?
Well, not every one. Try it. See how it sounds.
That's beautiful. What is it?
Just an old folk melody.
I've never heard you play with such feeling.
Geordi. Is there a problem?
I hear music.
Music?
I do not hear anything.
Are you sure?
I know I heard something.
It's stopped.
... I'd heard about Kerelian tenors all my life, but nothing could've prepared me for that man's voice. Soaring... incredible range.
I'm told there are nuances only Kerelians can hear -- we don't have the ears for it.
I should be finished with my survey by eleven hundred hours.
Very good, Commander.
Commander, we've finished the warp field test.
You brought it in ahead of schedule.
No problem. We got modulation efficiency up point five percent.
Good work. Notify Spectral Analysis they can have an hour on the main sensor array.
Captain... The Federation Outpost on Bersallis Three reports that they are entering a period of fire storm activity.
Is the outpost in any danger?
No, sir. The storm is heading for the northern continent, which is not populated.
Bersallin fire storms come in seven year cycles -- this might be a good chance to study them.
We have two days before our rendezvous with the Havana...
Helm, set course for Bersallis Three. Warp five.
Counselor, would you join me in my Ready Room?
You have the Bridge, Number One.
I wanted to talk to you about a matter of... protocol. I know there are no Starfleet regulations about a Captain becoming involved with a fellow officer, but...
You'd like my opinion about you and Commander Daren.
It's that obvious?
Obvious in way that pleases people who care about your happiness? Yes, it is.
But I have to be concerned about more than my own happiness.
And you think that perhaps your feelings toward Nella could change the way you function as Captain...
Yes. Relationships with coworkers can be fraught with consequences.
That's true. But cutting yourself off from your feelings can carry consequences that are just as important.
I've always believed that becoming involved with someone under my command could compromise my objectivity. And yet...
Captain... are you asking my permission?
If I were... would you give it?
Yes.
Come in.
Nella...
Can I help you, sir?
I'm sorry about what happened this morning in the Turbolift. When that crewman walked in I felt... self-conscious. It might take me a while to get used to the idea of the crew seeing us together.
I understand...
I'm glad you told me. For a minute there I thought I'd misread you... One kiss and you're off to find someone else.
I promise you... I'm not one for casual relationships.
There's something I want to tell you...
But not here...
Do you remember that folk melody I played for you this morning?
I learned it on a planet called Kataan.
Never heard of it.
I'm not surprised. Its sun went nova over a thousand years ago.
I don't understand.
The Enterprise encountered a probe sent from the planet before it was destroyed. The probe scanned me -- I lost consciousness, and in the space of twenty-five minutes... I lived a lifetime there.
I had a wife... children.
It was all very real to me.
When I awoke, all that was left of my life there... was the flute I'd taught myself to play.
Why are you telling me all this?
Because I want you to understand what my music means to me. And what it means for me to be able to share it with someone.
Thank you.
Commander --
I was hoping to talk to you about Ensign Cabot's transfer.
Quantum Mechanics didn't want to give him up.
But he wants to come to my department.
How do you know that?
I offered it to him.
Transfers have to be cleared through me -- before an offer's made.
I'm sorry. We were just talking and --
It's okay. But Fontana should stay where he is.
Commander, please... don't make that decision final. I realize I shouldn't have made the offer, but he's perfect for the job. And quantum mechanics is over-staffed anyway.
Commander... do you realize the position you're putting me in?
I think I'm just doing what any good department head would do -- trying to build the best staff I can.
Look... I'll review the situation and let you know as soon as I can.
Come.
Can I have a minute?
Of course. Come in.
It's about Lieutenant Commander Daren... As a department head, she comes to me about systems allocation, personnel transfers -- things like that.
I have to say, I'm beginning to feel... uncomfortable dealing with her requests.
Because of her relationship with me.
Yes.
Number One... are her requests unusual?
No, sir.
Would you say she's just trying to do her job?
Yes.
Then let her. And feel free to do yours.
Ship's resources are your responsibility. I've always had complete confidence in your judgment.
Thank you, sir.
... I can't believe I'm going to get a chance to study the fire storms on Bersallis. Did you know they're generated by solar flare activity? Apparently the radiation --
I'm boring you.
It's not that.
Commander Riker came to talk to me this afternoon. About you.
About the personnel transfer?
I thought he felt uncomfortable. Did he think I was asking for special treatment?
I was just doing what I thought was best for my department.
That's what I told him. But we have to be very careful. Obviously it's easy for people to misunderstand.

I don't like the thought of having to second-guess people all the time. If I have to worry about what people are thinking about me, I'll be concentrating on the wrong thing. And I won't be as effective an officer.
All I'm saying is that it's something we have to be aware of. But don't compromise yourself, do what you have to do.
Because if I find out that the head of Stellar Sciences isn't effective anymore, I'll do what I have to do... I'll replace her.
Noted, sir.
I suggest we forget about this and enjoy the evening.
What about that dessert you promised me?
Ah, yes. A concoction I first sampled on Thelka Four...
Bridge to Captain. Bersallis Three reports that the storm has changed its speed and heading. They are predicting it will hit the outpost within eight hours and are requesting evacuation.
On my way.
Captain's Log, Stardate 46693.1. We have entered the Bersallis star system and are making preparations to evacuate the Federation Outpost on the third planet.
The fire storms can kick up winds of over two hundred kilometers per hour -- and temperatures as high as three hundred degrees C.
Incredible... what causes them?
They form when solar flare radiation from the Bersallin sun reacts with high energy plasma present in the planet's atmosphere.
Wasn't the outpost built to withstand the conditions?
Yes; the structure is reinforced and insulated. But this is no ordinary storm; it's twice as big as any they've ever had. The outpost won't withstand it.
We'll be arriving a little over an hour before the storm hits. It'll take at least two hours to transport all the colonists off the surface.
I led a team of geologists to study the plasma geyser on Taurus Four -- we cross-connected a few thermal deflector units to create a protective shield against the heat.
A fire wall...
Could something like that work here?
It might.

The storm is approaching the outpost from this direction. If we set up a series of thermal deflector units along the northern perimeter, we could create a fire wall to deflect some of the heat -- the outpost's insulation could probably handle the rest.
Thermal deflectors generate a field approximately four hundred meters wide. We would need to cross-connect six units and align them so their fields overlap.
How many people would it take to set it up?

Twelve, two per team. Cross-connecting that many units will be tricky; once they're set up we'll have to leave them in place and transport our people out -- no one could survive very long outside the outpost.
Let's do it.
The storm's going to interfere with communications -- everything'll have to be coordinated from the surface.

Mister Data, you'll coordinate the evacuation of the colonists. Doctor, they have nine patients in the outpost infirmary. Your priority will be getting them to Sickbay -- after that you'll stay aboard the Enterprise and be ready to receive casualties. Marquez, you'll take some people down to track the storm -- you'll need to keep all teams apprised of its heading. Commander, you'll coordinate the deployment of the deflectors.
Let's go.
Commander Daren... ?
About these thermal deflectors...
It seems to me that any one of a number of people could coordinate their deployment.
I assume Commander Riker chose me because I'm the best person for the job.
Didn't we agree not to let our relationship get in the way of our work?
I'll be all right.
Lieutenant Marquez is already set up on the surface. Apparently the storm is still gaining speed -- he's estimating it'll hit the colony in less than fifty minutes.
Energize.
How long before the storm reaches the outpost?
Seventeen minutes.
La Forge to Bridge.
Go ahead.
The ionization from the storm is interfering with the transporters. I'm compensating, but it's slowing things down.
Keep at it, Mister La Forge.
Riker to Daren.
Daren, here. Go ahead, Commander.
You've got less than nine minutes before the storm reaches the northern perimeter.
I'm with team six right now, sir. We're about to bring the deflectors on-line.
Whenever you're ready.
Daren to perimeter teams. Stand by to cross-connect deflectors...
Activate.
Team three, increase your output by point two percent. Good... Deng, decrease nutation by point four percent.
Good... we've almost got it.
Crusher to Bridge.
Go ahead, Doctor.
I've just brought aboard the last of the infirmary patients and they're on their way to Sickbay. But we still have over a hundred colonists down there.
Understood, Doctor.
Daren to Commander Riker.
Riker, here. Go ahead.
We've got a problem --
... we're having trouble keeping the deflectors cross-connected. The only way this is going to work is if we calibrate them manually.
If you stay with the deflectors, will they protect you when the storm hits?
I don't know, sir. For a few minutes... maybe.
Number One, how many colonists are left to transport?
Seventy three, sir.
How long do you need?
At least ten more minutes.
Captain, the storm will reach the northern perimeter in four minutes.
Picard to perimeter teams.
... It is imperative that you hold your positions until we finish the evacuation of the colony. Picard out.
Picard to La Forge.
La Forge here.
Keep a signal lock on all perimeter team members.
Captain, the storm's interference won't --
As soon as the last of the colonists are evacuated I want those perimeter teams out of there. Is that understood?
Yes, sir.

Daren to perimeter teams... the storm's interference is going to make our job harder than we thought. We may lose communication, so it's up to each of you to keep your units operational. A lot of people are depending on us. Daren, out.
Oh, my god.
The storm has reached the perimeter.
I got out with the last of the colonists. If it hadn't been for the perimeter teams, we wouldn't have made it.
We managed to get four of the teams off the surface. The interference kept us from getting the other two... I don't see how they could have survived.
Which teams are missing?
Three and six.
The last I knew, Commander Daren was with team six.
Bridge to Captain.
Go ahead, Mister Worf.
We've found survivors, sir.. They're beaming up now.
On my way.

Captain's Log, Stardate 46697.2. Although we succeeded in rescuing all six hundred forty-three Bersallin colonists... we lost eight crewmembers. Let the record show that they gave their lives in the performance of their duty. Commendations will follow.
... when communications went out, I knew we had to fend for ourselves.

We modified our phasers to create resonant disruptions in the deflector field... the disruptions formed small pockets inside the plane of the field... and we each stood inside one to wait out the storm. Richardson didn't make it... all Deng and I could do was stand there... and watch.
Nella... you know I had to give that order --
Don't... don't say you're sorry.
It couldn't have been easy for you... hearing me order you to face death.
At first, when I heard you tell us to hold our positions, I didn't question it. Of course we would... that was our job. But when I saw that storm coming toward us...
Part of you must have... blamed me.
A small part, maybe... But in the end, I was more afraid that you would blame yourself if I died.
Would you have?
I've lost people under my command... people I cared about deeply... but never someone I've been in love with.

When I thought you were dead, I went into some kind of shutdown... I didn't want to think, I didn't want to feel. I was here, in my quarters, and... the only thing I could focus on was music... and how it would never give me joy again.
Well... where do we go from here?

We could continue... hoping we wouldn't face a situation like that again... knowing that we might... hoping the pressures on us wouldn't begin to erode our feelings for each other... That's not what I want for us.
I know. Neither do I.
I don't think we can serve on the same ship.
It would be difficult... for both of us.
I'll put in for a transfer.
We can arrange shore leave together.
Yes, of course.
Promise me something?
Don't give up your music.
Open hailing frequencies.
Hailing frequencies opened.
Repulse, this is the Enterprise. We are getting underway.
Acknowledged, Enterprise. Transfer complete -- good luck on your mission.
And to you.
Give my regards to your captain. Repulse out.
The Shuttle Bay is secure.
Thank you Mister Crusher. Make all preparations to get underway.
We will construct this large enclosure on Cargo Deck Five.
Come.
The transfer is complete. Doctor Pulaski is being shown to her quarters. We are ready to get underway.
Very good. Take a look at the containment module our new chief engineer has designed.
"Chief engineer," that has a nice ring to it.
It does to me. Each will have total atmospheric control... temperature, radiation, light, humidity, plus electrical spectrums.
And these are put into the large containment area?

Yes, these modules will keep the specimens alive -- the large containment area will keep us alive. Now, I have to go and replicate this five hundred and twelve times. This will mean it will be necessary to divert power from the warp engines to the replicator.
How long will we be on impulse power?
For a few hours, but it can't be helped.
When we leave 'aucdet Nine - I'm going to want all the power you can slam into those warp engines.
You'll have it.
I will relieve you at zero three zero zero.
Take us out of orbit, Mister Crusher -- set course for 'aucdet Nine.
Aye, sir. Course for 'aucdet Nine has been input.
Maximum impulse velocity.
Aye, sir.
Engage.
Engineering -- this is Science One. I just observed what appeared to be a random energy transference.
Where?
Aft. Outboard of the port nacelle.
Hold on -- I'll check.
No -- I show nothing here, Data.
Problem, Commander?
Possibly. An unexplained power fluctuation.
Let me know if it reoccurs.

Captain's log, Stardate 42073.1. There has been an outbreak of a yet unclassified Plasma Plague in the densely populated Rachelis system. We are on an emergency run to a Federation Research station on 'aucdet Nine, where specimens of Plasma Plague are kept. We will then transport that deadly cargo to Science Station Tango Sierra, where hopefully an antidote can be manufactured. Every hour we delay, thousands die.
How's it going?
Finished, just waiting to insert the modules.
Number One.
Lieutenant La Forge says we will be able to engage the warp drive within the hour.
Mister Data, when we receive a complete list of all the specimens we will be carrying, I want you and Doctor Pulaski to go through it... by the way. Where is our new doctor? Has she reported in?
Not yet.
Sickbay, this is the captain.
Sickbay, aye.
Is Doctor Pulaski there?
Ah... no, Sir. The doctor is in Ten-Forward.
What?! (surprised, then annoyed) A few hours on board and she's already found Ten-Forward.
I'll go and get her.
No, Number One. I'll go.
Not the best way to meet your new captain.
Hello, Captain.
Ensign Crusher.
I'm sorry this mission will delay your reunion with your mother.
It's all right. I can use the time to finish some projects.
We shouldn't be more than a week or so.
It is going to be hard to leave the Enterprise...
Mixed feelings for all of us.

It's always difficult leaving any ship, as it was for your mother when she left to become head of Starfleet Medical. But going from one assignment to another is part of the life which you are choosing.
Yes, but this isn't "any" ship.
Truly.
Guinan.
Captain.
Where's Doctor Pulaski?
Doctor Katherine Pulaski?
Ah... you must be Captain Picard...
Doctor -- protocol on your last assignment might have been lax, but here on the Enterprise...
(she abruptly cuts him off) Sit down, Captain. You better listen to this.
(he touches his communicator) Lieutenant La Forge, status report.
The containment area is completed, the last of the modules are being inserted.
Take us to warp six as soon as possible.
Acknowledged.
This is Doctor Katherine Pulaski. We will handle the formal introduction later.
Counselor Deanna Troi is pregnant.
A baby!
This is a surprise.
More so for me.
This pregnancy is unlike anything I have ever encountered. Since she came to me a few hours ago, I have made two complete examinations of Counselor Troi.
This is from the first examination. The fetus is about halfway through the first trimester -- about six weeks old. Understand, we...
(indicating herself and Troi) ... believe conception occurred about eleven hours ago.
What?
It gets better.
The second exam, an hour later was consistent, except for the fact that the fetus "appeared" to be several weeks older.
At this growth rate, Counselor Troi will have her baby within the next thirty-six hours. The normal gestation for a Betazoid is ten months.
I do not mean to be indelicate, but... ... who's the father?
Last night, while I slept... something... which I can only describe it as a presence, entered my body.
A life-form of unknown origin and intent is breeding right now inside Counselor Troi. Our purpose here is to determine what is to be done about this very "unusual" situation. Discussion.
Let me get this straight -- Deanna was impregnated by... by what? Doctor, what do your tests show? Is it a humanoid? An alien?
It's a male human... or in this case half-human -- half-Betazoid.
Exactly the same as Deanna!
In every way. There is no indication from any of my tests of any other genetic patterns except hers.
I don't think this is a random occurrence. There is a purpose here -- a reason. What, I don't know.
Captain, obviously the pregnancy must be terminated.
Why?
For the safety of the ship and crew.
Worf, you can't assume its intent is belligerent.
That is my safest assumption.
Captain, this is a life-form. Not to allow it to develop naturally would deny us the opportunity to study it.
If the fetus is aborted, laboratory analysis is still possible.
Is there any health risk to Counselor Troi if the fetus is aborted?
Medically, no.
Doctor, is that your recommendation?
Captain, do whatever you feel is necessary to protect the ship and the crew... but know this. I am going to have this baby.
I believe that ends the discussion.
Captain's log, supplemental. We have finally arrived at 'aucdet Nine. We will pick up the specimens of Plasma Plague and transport them to Rachelis.
It is only because so many lives are at stake that I am willing to put this ship and crew at such great risk.
How are you feeling?
I should be feeling uncomfortable with all the changes in my body... but, I'm not. I feel fine -- better than fine. Wonderful.
Standard orbit.
Standard orbit, aye.
Open hailing frequencies.
Hailing frequencies open.
'Aucdet Nine, this is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the USS Enterprise.
Ah... yes... Enterprise you're here at last. Good.
Excuse me, to whom am I speaking?
Oh... I'm Lieutenant Commander Hester Dealt. The medical trustee of the Federation Medical Collection Station.
Are the specimens ready for transfer?
Yes, but with your permission I would like to inspect the containment area before we proceed. It is not that I doubt the ability of your crew; we just cannot afford a mistake.
I appreciate your caution -- in the same vein, I need a complete, detailed manifest of everything which you intend to bring on board my ship.
I will allow access to the computer banks.
Download the inventory and go through it with Doctor Pulaski. Number One, arrange to have Hester Dealt transported up.
Captain, I'm suddenly feeling a little tired. I'll be in my quarters if you need me.
It won't be long now. Soon you'll arrive and so many questions will be answered.
This is very good. Exactly what's needed.
I just followed your instructions.
Good. Exactly what I wanted.
Five hundred and twelve compartments. Individually controlled. Very good. Independent of one another. Perfect. Ah, they can be monitored from here. And, isolation is assured. Very, very good.
I wanted to be sure they wouldn't get out.
Good, Lieutenant. Very good indeed.
How's it coming, Mister La Forge?
It will be just a little while longer. I want to go over it again in more detail.
It will be another couple of hours, Commander.
You do understand, it's critical that we have zero growth.
Oh, yes. I understand. So, you go over it as many times as you want.

It's been fourteen hours since we arrived at 'aucdet Nine. Hester Dealt is making final selections of the specimens we will carry. Meanwhile, we continue to receive desperate pleas from the Rachelis System.
Captain, the final manifest has been received.
At last. Review it with Doctor Pulaski. I want both of you to be completely familiar with it.
Aye sir.
Data -- help me get to Sickbay.
It's time.
Oh, you bet it is. Let's get you into Sickbay.
Worf -- assemble your security team in Sickbay.
Is that necessary?
Yes -- captain's orders.
Strange to need armed guards in the delivery room.
Yes, and strange to think my child is the cause.
Before you referred to it as "the child," now it's become your child.
Yes, whatever his beginnings, that's what he's become.
How frequent are your contractions?
Very close together.
In all my other deliveries -- with a couple of exceptions -- the father was present.
Difficult under the circumstances.
It's unfortunate you have to go through this alone. It helps to have someone with you.
Perhaps I could serve in that capacity. I can quickly review the procedures I will be required to execute.
Troi is going to need the comfort of a "human" touch... Not the cold hand of technology.
Doctor. I think Commander Data will do nicely.
Your choice.
There is nothing specific you have to do, Data, you just have to be with me.
There is nothing to be nervous about.

This is very interesting to me. Although I understand in technical terms how life is formed, there is still a part of the process which eludes my understanding. I began my existence as an adult. I have no memory -- no cognizance of conception, birth, childhood, so to be allowed to witness this event is...
It's happening.
Doctor!
This is an impatient baby. He's eager to make his appearance.
I'll give you something for the pain. It won't in any way diminish the experience.
I have felt no pain.
None?
No... none at all.
Have your security team stand over there. I understand the need to have you here, but keep out from under foot.
Are easy births the norm for Betazoids?
Not according to my mother.
(as she hands it to Troi) It's a boy. A normal, healthy, six pound, three ounce baby boy.
(continuing; without any edge) You can come the rest of the way in now.
No threat here, Lieutenant, you and your men can relax... it's just a baby.
It was remarkable. Thank you for allowing me to participate.
Do you have a name?
Ian Andrew, after my father.
(she touches her communicator) Captain.
Picard here.
Counselor Troi is the mother of a very healthy baby boy. Mother and child are both doing well.
Counselor, my best wishes to you and your son.
Thank you, sir.
Have you been here all along?
Yes. He's beautiful, Deanna... just like his mother. I don't think you are going to be needed here, Lieutenant.
How do you feel?
Fine. Absolutely wonderful and thank you, Doctor... for everything.
(as she does a scan of Troi and the baby, her face registers surprise) Amazing.
Welcome to the bridge, Doctor. How's Counselor Troi? Did she have a good night?
I have delivered dozens of babies. But none like this. There was no pain, no trauma. It was effortless for both of them.
I'm not sure of your point.
She had the baby yesterday. If I were to examine her now, I would not be able to tell that she just had a baby, or ever had a baby. It's as though the incident never happened.
How long before we are ready to begin the transfer?
Two hours, nineteen minutes.
You have the Conn, Number One.
Aye, sir.
Doctor, you would accompany me, please. I think it's time I paid my respects.
Come in.
scene: 47   INT. CORRIDOR - ENTRANCE TO TROI'S QUARTERS

quote: I wanted to come by and see how you were and have a look at your...
... baby! My goodness.
How old is he?
In actuality a day.
Yes, but...
... In appearance, almost four earth years old.
Ian, say hello to Captain Picard.
You mean he can talk?
Hello.
Hello, Ian.
Don't worry. Everything is fine.

Captain's log, supplemental. We are faced with two major problems: Troi's child and the deadly cargo we are about to load, which is so desperately needed in the Rachelis system. In the hours since his birth, Troi's baby has continued to age and now appears, physically and mentally, to be a child of eight. And still there is no indication as to who he is, or why he is here.
Sickbay, this is the bridge. We are ready to begin loading.
We need a little more time. It's taking longer than we anticipated.
Data, (she says "Data" with a short A) look at this.
Data.
What?
My name. It is pronounced Data.
Oh?
You called me Data.
What's the difference?
One is my name and the other is not.
Is this possible?
In all of your neural nets, algorithms, and heuristics, is there some combination which makes up a circuit for bruised feelings?
Apparently so, because I think I just offended your tender sensibilities.
Possible?
(continuing; indicating the CRT) I am unfamiliar with these symbols.
It indicates a genetically engineered biological life-form.
About twenty percent of the specimens fall into that category. Some eager beaver at play.
Query... "eager beaver?"

In this case, 'eager beaver' refers to some overachieving genetic engineer, who probably for lack of something better to do forced this strain of virus to mutate, just to see how bad, bad can get. (touches her communicator) Captain Picard.
Picard here.
Just so you fully appreciate the risks we are about to take...
Enlighten me.
If the most innocuous specimen on the manifest list gets loose, it will destroy all life on the Enterprise in a matter of hours.
I understand, Doctor. Do you have a recommendation?
Considering how desperately this is needed, no I don't. Just want you to know what we're carrying.
Thank you, Doctor. Commander Data, if you have completed your review, you are needed in Transporter Room Three.
Yes, sir. Excuse me, Doctor.
That's okay... (with long A, then short A) Data, Data... whatever.
Ian!
He's a very tactile child. He wants to touch and feel everything.
Come on, sweetheart, time to go.
Unbelievable -- I think he's actually grown since you dropped him off.
I like it here, Mommy.
I thought you would. Thank Miss Gladstone for having you, and let's go get you something to eat.
Thank you.
Bye...
Thank you.
The transporter is not making a positive lock.
The built-in inhibitor is restricting onloading of life-forms known to be hazardous to the occupants of this ship. Have you attempted override?
I don't have the authority.
Computer, recognize -- Lieutenant Commander N-F-N, N-M-I, Data.
Authorization accepted.
Initiate override protocol.
Override protocol is not recommended in this situation.
Acknowledged. On my authority -- begin override.
Sequence complete.
Cargo Deck Five. We will commence transport on your command.
Transporter Three -- we are ready to receive.
Data, the first batch is in place. Ready for the next.
Inform me when loading is complete and the cargo secure.
Aye, sir.
I wanted to stop by and see how Ian was doing.
We're doing fine. I was just going to give Ian his supper.
Do you want your supper now, too?
No, Ian, but thank you for the invitation.
You're welcome.
Have you ever played with puppies?
They had a litter today in the nursery.
No, I have never played with puppies.
You'd like it. You should go to the nursery while the puppies are still there.
Perhaps later.
Ouch...
Ow... Mommy... ow...
Let me look at that.
It's not serious.
My face is wet.
Is it better now, sweetheart?
He allowed himself to be burned.
Yes, for the experience.
Who is he? Why is he here? What does he want?
Ian, could you tell us why you are here?
Because Mommy said it was time to eat.
No, I mean... why you are here on this ship?
I live here.
Ian, the captain wants to know if you are ready to tell us why you came here.
No. Not yet.
The answer is within him. When his cognitive powers develop sufficiently, he will be able to articulate it.
I hope he will tell us soon.
Captain to the bridge.
I'm on my way, Number One. Keep me apprised of his progress, Counselor.
(too late for Picard to respond) Bye...
The cargo has been loaded and is secure.
Take us out of orbit, Number One -- then set a course for Rachelis -- warp nine.
Can I get you something?
No. I just wanted to stand here.
I don't blame you -- it's beautiful.
Yes.
How about some nice Mareuvian Tea?
No. Nothing thank you.
You're going to be leaving soon.
Yes.
What do you see when you look out there?
Over there is the Lorenze cluster, and there Arneb and there Epsilon Indi.
No, I don't mean that. I mean when you look there don't you see your future?
It will still be there.
How about a cup of nectar direct from Prometheus?
No -- nothing. That's the third time you've asked me.
It's what I'm expected to do. Don't you always do what's expected?
I try to.
Even if it's not what you really want?
Sometimes. Sometimes you have to consider others more than yourself.
That's true. But sometimes the game is to know when to consider yourself more than others and to give yourself permission to be... selfish.
Something's wrong.
What is it?
Growth.
Where?
L-seven-three.
(touches his communicator) Bridge, this is Cargo Deck Five.
Yes, Lieutenant La Forge.
There is a malfunction in the containment area.
How serious?
Very.
Captain's log, supplemental. For reasons as yet unknown, one of the specimens of Plasma Plague is growing.
(touches his communicator) Captain, the power to the containment grid must have somehow been affected when we increased to warp velocity.
I don't see how that would be possible.
I don't either, but if we could return to impulse, we would know for sure.
Impulse velocity.
Report, Mister La Forge.
There's no change. It wasn't the warp drive.
Permission to leave the bridge.
Granted.
Commander Data, you're with me.
Doctor Pulaski.
Yes, Captain.
We are having some difficulties on Cargo Deck Five -- your presence is requested.
I'm on my way.
You never talk about yourself.
Sure I do... all the time.
People say you are very old...
Oh?
... and that you knew Captain Picard when he was on the Stargazer.
No. I never met the captain until I came onboard.
Everyone is very curious about you.
I'll bet they are.
About where you come from.
Where do they say?
I heard that you're from Nova Kron and that...
Mister Crusher, report to the bridge.
I've got to go.
Thank you.
There's nothing like a dish of Delovian souffle.
I didn't mean the souffle, I meant for... well... the rest. Thanks.
That's why I'm here.
Take the Conn, Mister Crusher.
On this course -- increase velocity to warp nine.
Aye, sir. Warp nine.
Why that module and not the others?
Computer, run diagnostic on module L-seven-three.
All circuits functional.
Temperature -- as set -- minus ninety-seven degrees. Humidity -- twelve percent. Lumins -- zero. Electromagnetic containment integrity... Everything right down the line... exactly as it should be.
Perhaps it is a sensor malfunction. Computer -- query. Is growth actually occurring?
Confirmed.
One of the specimens is growing.
Destroy it, now.
I can't.
Data, prepare to jettison that module.
We can't do that either. It will go into a spore and remain until it comes in contact with a planet or another ship. The results would be disastrous.
Commander, your attitude tells me that however bad I think this is... it's worse.
(he indicates the containment area) This is not going to hold it.
Go on.
The rate of growth is increasing. Within thirty minutes it will push out of the module. Within two hours, it will breach the containment area.
It can't break through this.
Yes it can.

(touches his communicator) Captain. We may not be able to get control of this situation. I recommend making arrangements to transfer all non-essential personnel to the saucer section. If we lose containment we should be prepared to separate.
Make it so.
Why this one specimen and none of the others? Something is stimulating it. Do you have its etiology? How it was developed?

It's a mutated strain developed by Doctor Susan Nuress during an outbreak of Plasma Plague seventy years ago in the Oby System. (she pauses as she continues to read) It was number nine in a series of tests. This particular one bombarded by low levels of Eichner radiation. (then she turns to Hester) Could exposure to Eichner radiation stimulate growth?
Yes, it could, but...
Uh, oh...
Don't tell me.
I'm detecting low levels of Eichner radiation.
Why didn't you catch it before?
Because it wasn't here before..
Well, it is now. What emits that type radiation?
A subspace phase inverter.
We don't have one.
Certain cyanoacrylates.
Also, not on this ship... What else? Because it's here and we better find it.
I can feel that some of the people are very... worried.
Yes. I feel it as well, but don't you worry.
It's me Mommy -- I'm the reason.
What?
It's me.
You?
Yes. I have to leave you now, or it will be very bad for everyone.
What are you saying?
I have to leave now.
Leave? (senses what he is about to do) You are going to die. No. No, you can't.
(continuing; she touches her communicator) Sickbay, this is Counselor Troi, I need the doctor in my quarters... right now. (then she lifts Ian to her) No... Ian... No.
It's Ian. Please... please hurry.
Save him, you must save him.
What happened? Did he eat anything? Did he fall?
No.
The child is the source of the unusual radiation.
He said he's the reason the ship is in danger.
That analysis is correct.
I'm losing life signs.
Oh, please. Please save him.
I'm sorry.
Captain. The containment field has stabilized.
Thank you, Lieutenant.
Then Ian was right. He was the cause.
Apparently so.

He is a life-force entity... as we passed each other in space he was curious and wanted to know about us, and he thought the best way to learn was to go through the process. To be born, to live as one of us and in that way to understand us.
Captain, he never meant any harm.
There was a moment when you smiled.
He said thank you. I told him we will miss him -- and I will.
Standard station approach, Mister Crusher.
Standard approach, aye.
Transporter Room Three, this is the captain. We have arrived. Let's make this transfer with all deliberate speed, and get on about our business.
Yes, sir.
I will be glad to be relieved of this cargo.
You have the bridge, Number One.
Yes sir.
Captain.
Yes Ensign?
Could I see you when you have a moment?
In my Ready Room when your duties permit.
Thank you, sir.
Good luck.
(touches his communicator) Data, you can lock on to the first group and begin transporting on my mark.
Come.
Yes, Ensign.
Captain... I have thought about this a lot. I want to remain on the Enterprise.
Oh. Have you discussed this with your mother?
No, before I do that, I wanted your permission to stay.
Wes, it's a little more complicated than that.
Captain, for right now... this is where I want to be. This is where I feel I belong.
Captain -- transfer complete. We are ready to leave orbit.
Make it so, Number One. Return to your position.
All stations secure.
Take us out of orbit, Mister Crusher and lay in a course for the Morgana Quadrant.
Yes, sir.
(loud enough for everyone to hear) Mister Crusher has requested to remain on the Enterprise.
I'm not surprised. How did you respond?
I haven't as yet, Number One. I don't think it's my decision alone. His remaining will cause difficulties for us all.
Yes, indeed. With his mother not around, who will see to his studies?
Exactly. That duty would fall to Commander Data.
And, who'll tuck him in at night?
Come on, Commander.
I will accept that responsibility.
Well, we know he'll get his sleep.
Then, Number One, that leaves you the task of guiding young Mister Crusher through his most hazardous journey -- from youth to man. Are you willing to serve?
Difficult question...
... Yes, I think I can do that.
All right then. Mister Crusher, communicate with your mother at Starfleet Medical headquarters. Give her my regards and tell her you have my permission to remain on board the Enterprise.
But, that I will abide by her wishes.
Yes, sir... thank you sir... I just know she'll agree.
Now -- if you have course and speed laid in.
Yes sir, they are.
Then, Mister Crusher -- engage.
Captain's log, Stardate 42303.7. The Enterprise is bound for Star Station India to rendezvous with a Starfleet courier.
Hopefully the mission will provide an opportunity to evaluate our newest staff officer...

In the short time she's been aboard, Doctor Pulaski has distinguished herself as a meticulous and competent physician. But can someone so focused on her own specialty also assume the broader duties of the ship's Chief Medical Officer?
... warp drive theory always came easy for me, but I'm looking forward to some hands on experience.
I'm sure we'll be able to accommodate you.
I know what you mean. It's a really electrifying experience to be down there where the action is. Whenever I push the drive past warp six I still get a lump in my throat.
Can I get you another?
Tell me Commander. Is it the custom on the Enterprise for the First Officer to wait on trainees?
If they were all like you, I'm certain it would be.
What's it like these days at the academy? Is Tsiolkovski still teaching Propulsion Theory?
Are you kidding? They'll have to tear down the building around him. The first time I saw him...
Same again.
Good to see you, Commander. When you missed your test this morning we all feared the worst.
My apologies, Doctor. A minor crisis... in Engineering.
You know, a Rheinman tissue sample sounds a good deal worse than it is. I can assure you there's no discomfort involved.
It's not that! It's just... my duties are so diverse. Suppose we leave the appointment open?
Spontaneity is the sand in the clockworks of science.
But it's just an unimportant detail...
If I didn't consider it important I wouldn't insist. Don't force me to relieve you of duty to make my point.
You can't be -- I'll work something out. But my schedule is tight for the next three or four days...
So I see.
Beautiful, isn't it?
The most beautiful thing I know.
Picard.
Captain, this is the bridge. We're receiving a distress signal on an open sub-space frequency.
Sound emergency stations, and respond on the same frequency.
Sickbay on full emergency status, Captain.
Stand by, Doctor. Commander Data. Have we locked on to the signal yet?
Yes, sir. A voice only transmission from the USS Lantree, a Federation supply ship.
Lantree, this is Jean-Luc Picard of the USS Enterprise. What is the nature of your emergency?
-- can't hold out any -- dying -- too many -- help ...
Sir, we are still recieving their signal. There is simply no message.
Lantree! Are you under attack?
USS Lantree, this is the Enterprise, come in, Lantree.
Replay that last transmission.
-- can't hold out any -- dying -- too many -- help ...
Counselor?
Great stress is all I'm able to sense.
Have we got a fix on her?
Two point two milli-parsecs, bearing three-zero at one-four- five degrees.
Number One?
We better take a look. What vessel is it?
USS Lantree, a class R Starfleet supply ship assigned to Gamma seven seven, Captain L.I. Taleka commanding. Normal complement, twenty-six officers and crew.
Armed?
Class three defensive only.
Is she still underway?
Indeed. She is at maximum speed.
